facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 72 of 1952 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 72 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Judgment and Order dated 30th November 1950 of High Court of Judicature at Nagpur by Dev and Rao JJ. in Contempt proceedings Miscellaneous Petition No. 16 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 30th November, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur  Dev and Rao JJ.  in Contempt of Court Proceedings Miscella

facts.text: Shri Shareef was one of the appellants and at one time was Minister for Law and Justice in the State.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Shareef, one of the appellants, at one time was Minister for Law and Justice in the State. Dr. Kathalay, the second appellant, is a Doctor of Laws and an author of legal works.

facts.text: Dr. Kathalay is the second appellant, a Doctor of Laws and author of legal works.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Kathalay, the second appellant, is a Doctor of Laws and an author of legal works.

facts.text: Contempt proceedings taken against two senior members of Nagpur Bar and their client Shri Zikar.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of contempt proceedings taken against two very senior members of the Nagpur Bar and one of their clients.

facts.text: Shri Zikar made application under Article 226 for enforcement of fundamental right, alleging he was citizen of Bharat and Custodian and police treating him as Pakistan national.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Zikar who was charged along with the two appellants for contempt made an application under article 226 1  of the Constitution for enforcement of his fundamental right, alleging that he was a citizen Of Bharat and that the Custodian of Evacuee Property and the police were taking wrongful action against him and treating him as a national of Pakistan which he never was.

facts.text: High Court granted interim order of prohibition against State deporting Zikar after expiry of permit.

anchor.surface_text: He prayed for an interim order of prohibition against the State from deporting him after the expiry of the permit. The High Court granted the interim order of prohibition against the action complained.

facts.text: On 11th August 1950, at hearing, State raised preliminary objection that Zikar suppressed material facts.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the case on 11th August, 1950, a preliminary objection was raised on behalf of the State that Zikar had suppressed material facts in the petition filed by him and that the petition was therefore liable to be dismissed without going into the merits.

facts.text: Shri Shareef, counsel for Zikar, combated the contention.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Shareef, who was counsel for Zikar, combated this contention and further submitted that the preliminary objection could be adequately dealt with without going into the merits of the case.

facts.text: State filed another affidavit on 17th August 1950 stating certain facts.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the State another affidavit was filed on 17th August, 1950, stating certain facts, and Zikar was also directed to file an affidavit in reply by the 21st August, 1950, and this be did by that date.

facts.text: Zikar filed affidavit in reply by 21st August 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and Zikar was also directed to file an affidavit in reply by the 21st August, 1950, and this be did by that date.

facts.text: On 21st August 1950, proceedings: affidavits and copies filed, attention drawn to para 4 and 6, remarks about Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant proceedings of that date are recorded in these terms- Shri Shareef for the petitioner. Shri Naik for the respondent. He files an affidavit and copies of applications dated 25th February, 1949 and 19th January, 1950. Shri Shareef files a statement and an affidavit. His attention was drawn to paragraph 4 of the affidavit and he was asked whether his client has really understood the contents which are in English adding that he might change in the Supreme Court and say that he had not understood them.

facts.text: Shri Shareef informed court he wants time to apply for transfer due to observations on paras 4 and 6.

anchor.surface_text: When we reassembled Shri Shareef informed us that he wants time to apply for transfer of this case to another Bench because of the observations made by us regarding paragraphs 4 and 6 of his affidavit.

facts.text: Case adjourned to 25th August 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Case is therefore adjourned to 25th August, 1950 to enable Shri Shareef to make an application in the meanwhile.

facts.text: On 23rd August 1950, application for transfer filed alleging judges prejudiced, references to Supreme Court unnecessary.

anchor.surface_text: On the 23rd August, 1950, an application for the transfer of the case from the Bench hearing it to another Bench of the High Court was made on the following grounds 1 The observations and references to the Supreme Court by Rao and Deo JJ. created a bona fide belief in the applicants mind that they were prejudiced against him and had made up their minds and indicated that he shall have to go in appeal to the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Transfer application signed by Zikar, Shri Shareef and Dr. Kathalay as counsel.

anchor.surface_text: This application was not only signed by Zikar but also by the two appellants as counsel for the applicant

facts.text: Transfer application rejected.

anchor.surface_text: and was rejected in due course and with that matter we are no longer concerned.

facts.text: Preliminary objection upheld, Article 226 petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The preliminary objection raised by the State was upheld and the petition under article 226 was dismissed.

facts.text: Notices issued to Zikar and his two counsel to show cause why commit for contempt for scandalizing court via transfer application.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges then ordered notices to issue to the applicant and his two counsel to show cause why they should not all be committed for contempt for scandalizing the Court, with a view to perverting the due course of justice by making statements in the transfer application impeaching the impartiality of the Judges.

facts.text: Dr. Kathalay filed written statement in reply on 4th October 1950, denying contempt, expressing regret.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Kathalay filed his written statement in reply to the show cause notice, on the 4th October, 1950. He averred that he could not honestly admit that he scandalized the Court and committed contempt either in fact or in law ... Whatever the circumstances, I do see how much this application for transfer dated the 23rd August, 1950, has hurt the feelings of the Honble Judges and I very much regret that all this should have happened.

facts.text: Shri Shareef filed similar written statement, expressed regret, further statement on 16th October 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Shareef also put in a similar written statement. ... Further written statement was filed by Shri Shareef on 16th October, 1950.

facts.text: High Court held transfer application constituted contempt, advocates guilty, fined Shareef Rs. 500 or 2 weeks SI, Kathalay Rs. 1000 or 1 month SI.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in a very lengthy judgment ... held that the application for transfer constituted contempt because the Judges were scandalized with a view to diverting the due course of justice. The two advocates who signed and prosecuted the application were found guilty of contempt. ... We accordingly sentence Shri M. Y. Shareef to pay -a fine of Rs. 500 or in default to undergo simple imprisonment for two weeks and we Sentence Dr. D.W. Kathalay to pay a fine of -Rs. 1000 or in default to undergo simple imprisonment for one month.

facts.text: High Court refused leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Leave to appeal to this Court was refused but was granted here.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Leave to appeal to this Court was refused but was granted here.

facts.text: On 12th May 1954, appellants tendered unqualified apology to Supreme Court, appeal adjourned for two months, apology sent to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On the 12th May, 1954, when the appeal was heard by this Court, we recorded the following order- The appellants have tendered an unqualified apology to this Court and to the High Court, and they are prepared to purge the contempt for which they have been convicted. ... We therefore adjourn this appeal for two months and direct that the apology tendered here be tendered to the Division Bench before which the contempt is said to have been committed.

facts.text: High Court did not accept the apology, no remission of sentence.

anchor.surface_text: When the case went back to the High Court, it again took an unfortunate turn. The learned Judges ... answered thus We are constrained to observe that the spirit in which the apology was tendered here is not much different from that originally shown. ... In the result the apology was not accepted

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 15, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. October 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MEHR CHAND MAHAJAN C.J.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld that transfer application constituted contempt and advocates guilty.

anchor.surface_text: no exception can be taken to the decision of the High Court that the application for transfer did constitute contempt because the judges were scandalized with a view to diverting the due course of justice, and that in signing this application the two advocates were guilty of contempt. That decision therefore stands.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside the fines, accepted unqualified apology as purging contempt.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we allow this appeal to the extent that the sentence of fine passed on both the appellants is set aside, -and the unqualified apology given by them to this Court and the High Court is accepted.

facts.text: There was misconception amongst a section of Nagpur Bar about advocates' responsibilities in signing transfer applications.

anchor.surface_text: The fact however remains, as found by the High Court, that there was at the time these events happened considerable misconception amongst a section of the Nagpur Bar about advocates responsibilities in matters of signing transfer applications containing allegations of this character.

facts.text: Counsel advised client to refrain from such applications scandalizing court.

anchor.surface_text: it should be widely made known that counsel who sign applications or pleadings containing matter scandalizing the Court without reasonably satisfying themselves about the prima facie existence of adequate grounds there for, with a view to prevent or delay the course of justice, are themselves guilty of contempt of Court, and that it is not duty of a counsel to his client to take any interest-in such applications on the other hand, his duty is to advise his client for refraining from making allegations of this nature in such applications.
Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 30th November, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur  Dev and Rao JJ.  in Contempt

Shri Zikar who was charged along with the two appellants for companytempt made an application under article 226 1  of the Constitution for enforcement of his fundamental right, alleging that he was a citizen Of Bharat and that the Custodian of Evacuee Property and the police were taking wrongful action against him and treating him as a national of Pakistan which he never was.
The preliminary objection raised by the State was upheld and the petition under article 226 was dismissed.
in Contempt of Court Proceedings Miscellaneous Petition No. 16 of 1950. Dr. Bakshi Tek Chand,  Hardyal, Hardy, B. R. Mandlekar, D. Kathalay, Ganpat Rai and K. L. Arora, with him  for the appellant.

concepts.interpretation: Unqualified and sincere apology purges the contempt even in borderline cases involving misconception of counsel's duties.
concepts.unlisted_description: Sincere unqualified apology accepted as sufficient to purge contempt where no contumacy

anchor.surface_text: On the 12th May, 1954, when the appeal was heard by this Court, we recorded the following order- The appellants have tendered an unqualified apology to this Court and to the High Court, and they are prepared to purge the contempt for which they have been convicted.

it should be widely made known that counsel who sign applications or pleadings containing matter scandalizing the Court without reasonably satisfying themselves about the prima facie existence of adequate grounds there for, with a view to prevent or delay the course of justice, are themselves guilty of contempt of Court, and that it is not duty of a counsel to his client to take any interest-in such applications on the other hand, his duty is to advise his client for refraining from making allegations of this nature in such applications.

concepts.interpretation: Counsel's duty to court overrides duty to client; must not sign scandalizing pleadings without prima facie grounds; advise client against such.

issues.text: whether a counsel was guilty of contempt in signing such an application, or whether it was his professional duty to do so if his client was under that bona fide impression

anchor.surface_text: that the question did not concern him alone but the Bench and Bar generally and a question of great principle emerged, viz., whether a counsel was guilty of contempt in signing such an application, or whether it was his professional duty to do so if his client was under that bona fide impression.

issues.text: the question for consideration in the appeal now is whether the two appellants have purged the contempt by tendering an unqualified apology in this Court as well as to the High Court, the genuineness of which has been again emphasized by their counsel before us, or whether the sentence of fine awarded to them by the High Court should necessarily be maintained for upholding the authority and dignity of the Court

anchor.surface_text: In this situation, the question for consideration in the appeal now is whether the two appellants have purged the contempt by tendering an unqualified apology in this Court as well as to the High Court, the genuineness of which has been again emphasized by their counsel before us, or whether the sentence of fine awarded to them by the High Court should necessarily be maintained for upholding the authority and dignity of the Court

arguments.court_reasoning: Unqualified apology sincere and purges contempt given circumstances of misconception and no contumacy.

arguments.claim: There cannot be both justification and an apology; unqualified apology tendered purges contempt.

anchor.surface_text: In this situation, the question for consideration ... The proposition is well settled and self-evident that there cannot be both justification and an apology. The two things are incompatible.

arguments.claim: Considerable misconception amongst section of Nagpur Bar about advocates' responsibilities in signing transfer applications containing scandalizing allegations; duty to client does not prevail over duty to court.

anchor.surface_text: The fact however remains, as found by the High Court, that there was at the time these events happened considerable misconception amongst a section of the Nagpur Bar about advocates responsibilities ... his duty is to advise his client for refraining from making allegations of this nature in such applications.

arguments.claim: Act done under mistaken view of rights and duties; borderline case where principle to be settled; no contumacy in raising defence; unqualified apology sufficient to purge contempt.

anchor.surface_text: Once the fact is recognized ... it has to be held that the act of the two appellants in this case was done under a mistaken view of their rights and duties, and in such cases even a qualified apology may well be considered by a Court.

arguments.claim: Reference by judges to Supreme Court during hearing unfortunate and may have been misunderstood.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot help observing that the admitted reference by the judges to the Supreme Court in their remarks during the course of the hearing was unfortunate and seems to indicate an unnecessary and indecorous sensitiveness which may well have been misunderstood by the party and the advocates.

arguments.claim: Condemnation by High Court itself heavy punishment; unqualified apology sufficient; set aside fines.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we allow this appeal to the extent that the sentence of fine passed on both the appellants is set aside, -and the unqualified apology given by them to this Court and the High Court is accepted.

holdings.text: The application for transfer constituted contempt of court because the judges were scandalized with a view to diverting the due course of justice, and the two advocates were guilty of contempt in signing this application.

anchor.surface_text: no exception can be taken to the decision of the High Court that the application for transfer did constitute contempt because the judges were scandalized with a view to diverting the due course of justice, and that in signing this application the two advocates were guilty of contempt. That decision therefore stands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court's decision as no exception can be taken; stands as finding of guilt.

holdings.text: Counsel who sign applications or pleadings containing matter scandalizing the Court without reasonably satisfying themselves about the prima facie existence of adequate grounds therefor, with a view to prevent or delay the course of justice, are themselves guilty of contempt of Court, and it is not the duty of a counsel to his client to take any interest in such applications; on the other hand, his duty is to advise his client to refrain from making allegations of this nature in such applications.

anchor.surface_text: it should be widely made known that counsel who sign applications or pleadings containing matter scandalizing the Court without reasonably satisfying themselves about the prima facie existence of adequate grounds there for, with a view to prevent or delay the course of justice, are themselves guilty of contempt of Court, and that it is not duty of a counsel to his client to take any interest-in such applications on the other hand, his duty is to advise his client for refraining from making allegations of this nature in such applications.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Roots out misconception among Bar that duty to client prevails over duty to court; counsel must verify grounds before signing scandalizing matter.

holdings.text: The act of the two appellants was done under a mistaken view of their rights and duties; in borderline cases where a question of principle about the rights of counsel and their duties has to be settled, an unqualified apology purges the contempt.

anchor.surface_text: Once the fact is recognized ... it has to be held that the act of the two appellants in this case was done under a mistaken view of their rights and duties, and in such cases even a qualified apology may well be considered by a Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recognizes misconception and borderline nature; no contumacy in defense; apology sufficient despite initial justification.

holdings.text: The plea of justification in this case did not amount to contumacy.

anchor.surface_text: we have reached the conclusion contrary to that arrived at by the High Court that the plea of justification in this case did not amount to contumacy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Depends on circumstances and general impression of ethics in profession; necessary to settle point without viewing as aggravating contempt.

holdings.text: The unqualified apology tendered is accepted as sufficient to purge the contempt; sentence of fine set aside.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we allow this appeal to the extent that the sentence of fine passed on both the appellants is set aside, -and the unqualified apology given by them to this Court and the High Court is accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Peculiar circumstances, no contumacy, heavy punishment already via condemnation; dignity upheld by acceptance.

holdings.text: The reference by the judges to the Supreme Court during the hearing was unfortunate and may well have been misunderstood.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot help observing that the admitted reference by the judges to the Supreme Court in their remarks during the course of the hearing was unfortunate and seems to indicate an unnecessary and indecorous sensitiveness which may well have been misunderstood by the party and the advocates.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Observation on facts contributing to misunderstanding.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we allow this appeal to the extent that the sentence of fine passed on both the appellants is set aside, -and the unqualified apology given by them to this Court and the High Court is accepted.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed to the extent sentence of fine set aside; unqualified apology accepted as purging the contempt; conviction for contempt upheld; strong admonition and warning issued.
directions: Unqualified apology tendered to this Court and the High Court is accepted.
Strong admonition and warning issued to the two counsel for their conduct.

anchor.surface_text: it should be widely made known that counsel who sign applications or pleadings containing matter scandalizing the Court without reasonably satisfying themselves about the prima facie existence of adequate grounds there for, with a view to prevent or delay the course of justice, are themselves guilty of contempt of Court, and that it is not duty of a counsel to his client to take any interest-in such applications on the other hand, his duty is to advise his client for refraining from making allegations of this nature in such applications.
